content: The Act titled "Federal Facility Superfund Compliance Act of 1997" amends Section 120 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to focus on federal entities and facilities. The Federal Facility Superfund Compliance Act of 1997 amends Section 120 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to require all federal departments, agencies, and branches to comply with environmental regulations related to hazardous substances, pollutants, and contaminants, similar to non-governmental entities. This includes enforcement and liability provisions under sections 106 and 107 of the Act. The Federal Facility Superfund Compliance Act of 1997 amends Section 120 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to require federal compliance with environmental regulations, including administrative orders, penalties, and fines. The United States waives immunity for such requirements. The Federal Facility Superfund Compliance Act of 1997 amends Section 120 of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 to require federal compliance with environmental regulations, including administrative orders, penalties, and fines. The United States waives immunity for such requirements, and no agent, employee, or officer of the United States shall be personally liable for any civil penalty under any circumstances. The waiver of sovereign immunity for federal compliance with environmental regulations does not apply to federal departments, agencies, or instrumentalities if a state law imposes stricter standards on them than on others. The Administrator may issue orders under section 106 of the Act to any department, agency, or instrumentality of the United States, and enforcement actions will be initiated against them in the same manner as against any other person. Unless required by State law or Constitution, funds collected by a State from the Federal Government for penalties and fines related to environmental violations must be used for environmental projects or enforcement costs. Each department, agency, and instrumentality has contribution protection rights.
